6.19. Insurance.
6.19.1. Types and Amounts of Coverage. Throughout the entire Term, you must maintain such types of insurance, in such
amounts, as we may require. Such insurance is in addition to any other insurance that may be required by applicable law, your landlord, or
otherwise. Policies that we require must be written by an insurance company reasonably satisfactory to us with an A.M. Best rating of “A” or
better, and, must name us as an additional insured party. At a minimum, such policies must include the following:
(a) commercial general liability insurance, completed-operations and independent-contractors coverage in the amount of
$1,000,000, per person/per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage combined with a general aggregate of $3,000,000.

(b) workers’-compensation coverage in the amount of at least $100,000/$500,000/$100,000, unemployment insurance and
employer’s liability insurance, as well as such other insurance as may be required by statute or rule of the state in which the Franchised Business is
located;
(c) fire, lightning, vandalism, theft, malicious mischief, flood (if in a special flood-hazard area), sprinkler damage, and the
perils described in ex-tended-coverage insurance with primary and excess limits of not less than the full-replacement value of the supplies, furniture,
fixtures, equipment, machinery, inventory, and plate glass having a deductible of not more than $1,000 and naming us as a loss payee;
(d) automobile liability insurance-including coverage of vehicles not owned by you, but used by employees in
connection with the Franchised Business, with a combination of primary and excess limits of not less than $1,000,000;
(e) commercial blanket bond in the amount of $100,000; and
(f) such other insurance, in such amounts, as we reasonably require for our and your protection.

perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates specific minimum insurance coverages, fulfilling legal requirements. The modified text removes many specific coverage amounts (e.g., per person/per occurrence limit for commercial general liability, specific limits for workers' compensation, automobile liability) and significantly reduces the commercial blanket bond, allowing the franchisor to potentially require inadequate coverage and failing to meet the required insurance minimums. This creates legal risk as it violates standard business insurance mandates and potentially exposes the franchisee (and franchisor) to significant uncovered liability. By reducing the coverage amounts and removing specific coverages, the franchisee may not be adequately protected against potential liabilities, leading to legal action and financial losses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Varies by state, but generally violates standard business insurance requirements, such as minimum liability coverage, worker's compensation limits, and adequate property coverage.

perturbation.original_text:
25. DISPUTES
25.1. Submission to Mediation. Except as otherwise provided in Section 25.7 [Remedies Not Exclusive] below, any controversy or claim
arising between us will first be submitted to non-binding mediation administered by an established, neutral mediation service with experience in
franchise disputes. Both parties must sign a confidentiality agreement before participating in any mediation proceeding. The mediation will take
place in the city where our principal offices are located at the time the demand for mediation is filed. Once either party has submitted a dispute to
mediation, the obligation to attend will be binding on both parties. Each party will bear its own costs with respect to the mediation. The fee for the
mediation, however, will be split equally.
25.2. Forum for Litigation. You and the Owners must file any suit against us, and we may file any suit against you, in the federal or state
court where our principal office is located at the time the suit is filed. The parties waive all questions of personal jurisdiction and venue for the
purpose of carrying out this provision.
25.3. Mutual Waiver of Class Actions. Any lawsuit, claim, counterclaim, or other action may be conducted only on an individual basis,
and not as part of a consolidated, common, or class action.
25.4. Mutual Waiver of Jury Trial. You and we each irrevocably waive trial by jury in any litigation.
25.5. Mutual Waiver of Punitive Damages. Each of us waives any right to or claim of punitive, exemplary, multiple, or consequential
damages against the other in litigation and agrees to be limited to the recovery of actual damages sustained.

perturbation.explanation: The modifications to the dispute resolution clause significantly prejudice the franchisee. Removing the requirement for an 'established, neutral mediation service with experience in franchise disputes' and requiring the franchisee to pay the entire mediation fee is highly unfavorable. This violates principles of fair dispute resolution. The complete waiver of jury trial by the franchisee, while retaining it for the franchisor and waiving 'mutual' from the title, is similarly problematic. This creates a legal contradiction as it undermines the franchisee's right to a fair hearing and equal access to justice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of contract law regarding fairness, equal bargaining power, and unconscionability. Some state franchise laws may also address dispute resolution fairness.

19. INDEMNIFICATION
You agree to hold harmless, defend, and indemnify us and our past, present and future affiliates, officers, directors, shareholders, agents,
attorneys, consultants, and employees against any claims, losses, costs, expenses (including, but not limited to, reasonable attorneys’ fees, costs
of investigation, settlement costs, and interest), liabilities and damages (collectively, “Claims”) arising directly or indirectly from, as a result of, or in
connection with your activities under this Agreement. With respect to any threatened or actual litigation, proceeding, or dispute that could directly
or indirectly affect us or any of the other indemnitees under this Section, if you do not assume the active defense of the matter within a reasonable
time, we will have the right, but not the obligation, to: (i) choose counsel; (ii) direct and control the handling of the matter; and (iii) settle any claim
against the indemnitees. This Section will survive the expiration or termination of this Agreement, and applies to Claims even if they exceed the
limits of your insurance coverage.

19. INDEMNIFICATION
You agree to hold harmless and indemnify us and our past, present and future affiliates, officers, directors, shareholders, agents,
attorneys, consultants, and employees against any claims, losses, costs, expenses (including, but not limited to, attorneys’ fees), liabilities and damages (collectively, “Claims”) arising directly or indirectly from, as a result of, or in
connection with your activities under this Agreement. With respect to any threatened or actual litigation, proceeding, or dispute that could directly
or indirectly affect us or any of the other indemnitees under this Section, we will have the right, but not the obligation, to: (i) choose counsel; (ii) direct and control the handling of the matter; and (iii) settle any claim
against the indemnitees. This Section will survive the expiration or termination of this Agreement, and applies to Claims even if they exceed the
limits of your insurance coverage.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'defend' and removing 'reasonable' and 'costs of investigation, settlement costs, and interest' before attorneys' fees, this clause imposes an unreasonable burden on the franchisee. Removing the 'defend' language requires the franchisee to indemnify the franchisor even in cases where the franchisor is directly at fault, which some franchise laws prohibit. Removing 'reasonable' before 'attorneys' fees' and removes costs of investigation and settlement, makes the franchisee responsible for potentially exorbitant legal fees without any control. This creates a legal risk as it may be deemed unconscionable and unenforceable under certain state laws designed to protect franchisees from overreaching franchisors.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State franchise laws (e.g., California Franchise Relations Act) that prohibit franchisors from requiring franchisees to indemnify them for their own negligence or misconduct. Principles of contract law regarding unconscionability and good faith.
